Just got an edit approved on Grokpedia after the exact same issue got rejected the first time. Same article (DogeDesigner), same formatting problem, totally different outcomes.

Heres the difference between a bad edit suggestion and a good one. 

Bad edit (rejected):
Edit summary: "there is an issue with the markdown here."

Good edit (accepted): Edit summary: Explained exactly how the [](url) format was dumping raw URLs into the article, breaking consistency with the numbered [1][2] style used everywhere else, cited the guidelines, and provided clean replacement text + new reference.

Key takeaway for anyone editing Grokpedia:

- Be specific about what's wrong
- Show why it violates style/readability
- Offer a precise, minimal fix
- Reference the actual guidelines

Vague = rejected ğŸš« 
Clear + solution-oriented = accepted âœ…

The UK is regulating itself into irrelevance.

The plan was to build 531 km of high-speed rail.

Before laying track, contractors had to:

- Complete a 350-page â€œsocial valueâ€ assessment
- Guarantee 30% female representation
- Guarantee 20% ethnic-minority representation

The outcome was predictable.

- Original timeline: 2010-2026
- After years of delays and overruns, ~50% of the project was cancelled
- Remaining construction now stretches beyond 2033
- Cost: ~Â£70B for just 40% of the route (~Â£311M per km)

Meanwhile, China:

- Built ~50,000 km of high-speed rail in 17 years
- Averaging ~3,000 km per year
- At a cost of ~Â£14M per km

China builds high-speed rail ~200x faster and ~22x cheaper.

Now apply the same regulatory mindset to the energy transition....
and the scale of waste becomes obvious.
